title: There's no such thing as "unplayable champion"
body: Just because a champion is weak it doesn't mean they are unplayable. If you are devoted enough you can make that champion work.

replies.body:
there are however champions that are not competitive.

every champion is playable. even when he has a 30% average winrate. such a champion is still trash and feels like shit to play, since you have to put in 3 times the efford of your opponent to have an equal chance at winning.

I agree with this. I think the point here is that there are **easier** champs in the same class to do well with. Doesn't make them unplayable. META though stands for "most efficient tactics available." Easier champs are wayyyy more meta than champs with weird niches and special comp setups therefore making them more playable and accessible to the players in solo q.

> META though stands for "most efficient tactics available." Easier champs are wayyyy more meta than champs with weird niches and special comp setups therefore making them more playable and accessible to the players in solo q.

This is such a pile of crap, the vast majority(easily >90%) of competitive picks aren't niche champions in the slightest and are just overbearing nearly in complete disregard to any other picks made, sometimes they simply may demand the player to understand the champ/the game better than simpler picks, but it's very rare(basically shen, and sometimes 0-2 other champs) that a champ is good at competitive and bad in solo q, maybe bad when used by bad solo q players, but that's it.

I currently have a 63% win rate as {{champion:72}} top with a 3.25 KDA over 16 games.

I would also like to mention that there are diamond+ players who got to their spot by maining ANY given champ. (aside from the ones that most recently came out obviously).

In pro-play, you have champions who are just not viable and are completely out classed. This is not the case in solo queue.

Your skill level is decided by your average performance, to do well on any champion really isn't about being actually good at said champion, but just being worse at other things you play.
Or just being lucky, whatever.

> I would also like to mention that there are diamond+ players who got to their spot by maining ANY given champ. (aside from the ones that most recently came out obviously).

*There's slightly more to this than that(specifically various cheeses which rely on the enemy not knowing what they are playing against, but that doesn't make the champion good in any way)

> In pro-play, you have champions who are just not viable and are completely out classed. This is not the case in solo queue.

It depends on how you choose to view things, but I still remember the game(a competitive game, at worlds if I'm not mistaken) where one team picked veigar+nidalee bot out of disrespect, and won anyway, so you could say anything is viable in competitive as well.
It's really not the case, but these threads never are about making sense, they are about circlejerking.

Pretty sure it wasnt worlds(?) but I think I know what game you are talking about. There is a different game where faker wins a game as Yi mid... out of disrespect for the other team. Pretty sure that was just a Korean tournament though. Definitely not worlds.

I would simply argue that it isnt about being worse at other champions. Sometimes, a particular champion or playstyle just suits you better. Its about being good with THAT champion, not being bad with others. 

Its not about your comparative skill with other champions, but your success rate with said champion. Now, that doesn't mean that their are not other champions who are by the numbers better. That is most certainly the case. And if someone wanted to learn champion A over their favorite champion B because A does the same general stuff just better, they would probably have a higher chance of success once they were familiar enough. This is all true.

The point of this thread, and others like it, is to encourage people to play the game and ENJOY it by playing the champions that they personally like. Letting them know that it if you work at getting your champion down, and learn the core mechanics on how to actually win the game, you can climb. Thats all. Certainly not what I would call a circlejerk. (aka Yasuo op/ windwall op/ nerf riven wth threads)

Thing is for most levels of play, it is mostly not being as bad at a certain champion as you are at others, chances are that if you are better at some off meta champion than the meta champions, you either suck at the meta champions, or at the game(for example one of the reasons that I'm bad at lee sin(Aside from me being bad at lee sin), is that I'm just not a very good jungler overall, and lee sin is all about abusing his early game pressure to the max, which I'm not good at, due to not being a very good jungler).

As far as the yasuo circlejerk goes, it's not an easy one, A LOT of people hate/started hating yasuo on their own(there's a reason he is so wildly despised, he didn't just draw the short straw at a raffle), the lines between a circlejerk and just general opinions gets blurry there.

>META though stands for "most efficient tactics available."

It's a convenient acronym, but that isn't where the term "meta" comes from :P

In the context of League of Legends, yes, yes it is.  Just because it has other meanings, doesn't mean those are the meanings being used.  In LoL Meta means "Most Effective Tactic Available", everywhere else it refers to a space in which the fictional and or lesser world interacts with a real, or greater world, hence the terms Meta Humor, in the case of 4th wall breaking shows, and Meta-Physical refering to things of a more cosmic mean.  But in LoL, it was an accronym adopted to mean Most Effective Tactic Available.

No, it's a reference to metagaming, which is a thing that's existed long before LoL has. Your "most effective tactics available" is just a convenient acronym. And let's not even get into how what's meta and what's efficient aren't necessarily the same thing, otherwise people would stop copying the pros already and work with what actually works at their skill levels and solo queue (as opposed to pro level and cohesive team play).

Support Miss Fortunat was briefly meta. Support Miss Fortune was not always the best idea, but overplayed compared to where it was actually efficient (a specific counter to support Zyra).

The core of metagaming *is* to use the most efficient tactics possible, but your acronym is derived from metagaming--they're not mutually exclusive. The reason for my correction is that you're trying to tell me here that the effect (the acronym) has replaced the cause (metagaming), when in reality both cause and effect exist in the context of LoL. Meta in LoL came from metagaming, the acronym merely summarizes it.
Btw meta gaming actually refers to using resources outside the game, to make it easier, such as banning someone's listed best champs, which means you aren't even right in that respect.

>META though stands for "most efficient tactics available." 

Do people really not know what the 'meta' prefix actually means? That's something taught in early highschool...
Do you really not know what slang is?  Not everything keeps it's meaning in a change of context.  That's something taught in elementary school.

In this case it seems you went to a pretty shitty elementary school because you can't recognize what is and isn't slang. Metagame isn't slang. Meta is a prefix that is used to refer to self-reflexive concepts. Metalanguage is the language that is used within a language. Metafiction is a fiction within another work of fiction. Metagame is a game within another game. It's not a slang word, if anything it's quite scientific. And it definitely isn't an acronym. Meta in the context of LOL is still the same thing, metagame. The meaning didn't change at all. The word simply got shortened. 

You got called out on your bullshit, accept it and move on. It's more dignified than this mental gymnastics for damage control.

AND FURTHERMORE, that's not what meta means at all, meta is self referential, such as a character aknowledging that they're a character, a book pointing out in narration that it's fiction, you say the prefix meta is taught in early highschool; which by the way, it's taught as early as 2nd grade in the case of my niece, yet you don't even know the proper meaning.  Get the heck out of here until you know what you're talking about.

The point of this post isn't that no champion could theoretically ever be unplayable, the point is that League is incredibly well-balanced, and so no champion ever will be unplayable. Even champs who are intentionally kept weak maintain winrates above 45% unless they're high skill floor champs (see Kalista, Azir, and sort of Ryze).

I personally perform at the same level of efficiency no matter what champion I play (mostly). Any role, any champ.  There are, however, some champions I can not seem to find an efficient way to play, and they are the exception to my rule. 

While they are not unplayable, their efficiency in actual team play is extremely limited. Due to an inability to farm, lack of synergy with any other champion, or simply because they do not bring anything to the table that is not going to be immediately out classed by anything the opposing team picks for the same role... one can consider them unplayable. 

Myself and countless others can still perform fairly well with these champions, but we could literally pick any other and perform better.
